title.narrative: Support on WASH of communities in Miyo woreda

description.narrative: Capacity building and rainwater harvesting implementation for pastoralists
Contributing to the efforts of improved access to drinking water and sanitation and hygienic living conditions of pastoralist and agro pastoralist communities of Miyo Woreda.

Financial sustainability : This project is designed to have both the hard and soft ware components integrated. Active participation of all concerned stakeholders from project identification, planning, implementation, monitoring, and evaluation as well as transparent communication. Furthermore, the project will strive to build the operational capability of the beneficiary communities and other stakeholders.

Major project plan are construction of Birka having 300 m3 capacity at Cheri Liche PA and two sand dams having 3000m3 and 3600m3 capacities respectively at Cheri Turura and Meti. Other capacity building trainings including WASH Committee establishment at School and Community level, conduct Annual WASH campaign, establish water management committee.
Site selection, signing of project agreement with Donor, local community mobilization.

The project name is Local Capacity Building Support on WASH Practices of Pastoral Communities in Miyo with the project budget of 74,561.21 (53,303.20 and 21258 Euro to be raised from RAIN and ICCO). It has a total beneficiaries of 3168 (1528 F) people residing in target kebeles of Miyo Woreda. It has project period of one year, July 2012 - February 2013.

The proposed project is envisaged to be implemented in Miyo Woreda of Borana Zone, Oromia Regional State. Miyo is located at a distance of 763 kms along the Ethio-keniyan border. The woreda is structured in to 15 kebeles and with its capital town, Hidi.
The Woreda is characterized by an undulating plain with scattered and mostly bisected ridges usually covered with grass and shrubs. The rain fall pattern is bi-modal; there is a short rainfall period from September to November and a major rainy season occurring from March to May. Rainfall varies from 250 mm in the south to 1000 mm in the north-west; averaging 650mm.
The interventions are intended to address some of the major problems of the community in the area specifically with main aim of addressing the negative impacts of poor access to Water, Sanitation and Hygiene through construction of rainwater harvsting structures for safe and access to drinking water and mass mobilization.

Active participation of all concerned stakeholders from project identification, planning, implementation, monitoring, and evaluation as well as transparent communication. Furthermore, the project will strive to build the operational capability of the beneficiary communities and other stakeholders.
